entry.title: Hello World
entry.content:
Welcome to Hexo! This is your very first post. Check documentation for more info. If you get any problems when using Hexo, you can find the answer in troubleshooting or you can ask me on GitHub.

Quick Start

Create a new post

More info: Writing

Run server

More info: Server

Generate static files

More info: Generating

Deploy to remote sites

More info: Deployment

Animation

zustand

A small, fast and scalable bearbones state-management solution using simplified flux principles. Has a comfy api based on hooks, isnâ€™t boilerplatey or opinionated.
Donâ€™t disregard it because itâ€™s cute. It has quite the claws, lots of time was spent to deal with common pitfalls, like the dreadedÂ zombie child problem,Â react concurrency, andÂ context lossÂ between mixed renderers. It may be the one state-manager in the React space that gets all of these right.

Ultimate React Router v6 Guide

React Router Basics

Configuring The Router

To get React Router working in your app, you need to render a router element at or near the root of your element tree. We provide several different routers depending on where your app is running.

<BrowserRouter> or <HashRouter> should be used when running in a web browser (which one you pick depends on the style of URL you prefer or need)

These routers provide the context that React Router needs to operate in a particular environment. Each one rendersÂ a <Router>Â internally, which you may also do if you need moreÂ fine-grainedÂ control for some reason. But it is highly likely that one of the built-in routers is what you need.

BrowserRouter

<BrowserRouter>Â is the recommended interface for running React Router in a web browser. AÂ <BrowserRouter>Â stores the current location in the browserâ€™s address bar using clean URLs and navigates using the browserâ€™s built-in history stack.
<BrowserRouter window>Â defaults to using the currentÂ documentâ€™sÂ defaultView, but it may also be used to track changes to another windowâ€™s URL, in anÂ <iframe>, for example.

HashRouter

<HashRouter>Â is for use in web browsers when the URL should not (or cannot) be sent to the server for some reason. This may happen in some shared hosting scenarios where you do not have full control over the server. In these situations,Â <HashRouter>Â makes it possible to store the current location in theÂ hashÂ portion of the current URL, so it is never sent to the server.

<HashRouter window>Â defaults to using the currentÂ documentâ€™sÂ defaultView, but it may also be used to track changes to another windowâ€™s URL, in anÂ <iframe>, for example.

Defining Routes

Routing is the process of deciding which React elements will be rendered on a given page of your app, and how they will be nested. React Router provides two interfaces for declaring your routes.

  • <Routes>and <Route> if youâ€™re using JSX
  • useRoutes if youâ€™d prefer a JavaScript object-based config

[[router-v6-detailed#Routing|more details]]

Routes And Route

<Routes>Â andÂ <Route>Â are theÂ primary ways to render somethingÂ in React RouterÂ based on the currentÂ location. You can think about aÂ <Route>Â kind of like anÂ ifÂ statement; if itsÂ pathÂ matches the current URL, it renders itsÂ element! TheÂ <Route caseSensitive>Â prop determines if the matching should be done in aÂ case-sensitiveÂ manner (defaults toÂ false).

Whenever the location changes,Â <Routes>Â looks through all itsÂ childrenÂ <Route>Â elements to find the best match and renders that branch of the UI.Â <Route>Â elements may be nested to indicate nested UI, which also correspond to nested URL paths. Parent routes render their child routes by rendering anÂ <Outlet>.

The default <Route element> is an <Outlet>. This means the route will still render its children even without an explicit element prop, so you can nest route paths without nesting UI around the child route elements.

For example, in the following config the parent route renders an <Outlet> by default, so the child route will render without any surrounding UI. But the child routeâ€™s path is /users/:id because it still builds on its parent.

useRoutes()

The useRoutes hook is the functional equivalent of <Routes>, but it uses JavaScript objects instead of <Route> elements to define your routes. These objects have the same properties as normal <Route> elements, but they donâ€™t require JSX.

The return value of useRoutes is either a valid React element you can use to render the route tree, or null if nothing matched.

Handling Navigation

  • <Link>Â andÂ <NavLink>Â render an accessibleÂ <a>Â element, or aÂ TouchableHighlightÂ on React Native. This lets the user initiate navigation by clicking or tapping an element on the page.
  • useNavigateÂ andÂ <Navigate>Â let you programmatically navigate, usually in an event handler or in response to some change in state

Link

AÂ <Link>Â is an element that lets the user navigate to another page by clicking or tapping on it. InÂ react- router-dom, aÂ <Link>Â renders an accessibleÂ <a>Â element with a realÂ hrefÂ that points to the resource itâ€™s linking to. This means that things like right-clicking aÂ <Link>Â work as youâ€™d expect. You can useÂ <Link reloadDocument>Â to skip client side routing and let the browser handle the transition normally (as if it were anÂ <a href>).

A relativeÂ <Link to>Â value (that does not begin withÂ /) resolves relative to the parent route, which means that it builds upon the URL path that was matched by the route that rendered thatÂ <Link>. It may containÂ ..Â to link to routes further up the hierarchy. In these cases,Â ..Â works exactly like the command-lineÂ cdÂ function; eachÂ ..Â removes one segment of the parent path.

NavLink

AÂ <NavLink>Â is a special kind ofÂ <Link>Â that knows whether or not it is â€œactiveâ€œ. This is useful when building a navigation menu such as a breadcrumb or a set of tabs where youâ€™d like to show which of them is currently selected. It also provides useful context for assistive technology like screen readers.

By default, anÂ activeÂ class is added to aÂ <NavLink>Â component when it is active. This provides the same simple styling mechanism for most users who are upgrading from v5. One difference as ofÂ v6.0.0-beta.3Â is thatÂ  activeClassNameÂ andÂ activeStyleÂ have been removed fromÂ NavLinkProps. Instead, you can pass a function to eitherÂ styleÂ orÂ classNameÂ that will allow you to customize the inline styling or the class string based on the componentâ€™s active state. you can also pass a function as children to customize the content of theÂ <NavLink>Â component based on their active state, specially useful to change styles on internal elements.

Navigate

AÂ <Navigate>Â element changes the current location when it is rendered. Itâ€™s a component wrapper aroundÂ useNavigate, and accepts all the same arguments as props.

useNavigate()

TheÂ useNavigateÂ hook returns a function that lets you navigate programmatically, for example after a form is submitted.

TheÂ navigateÂ function has two signatures:

  • Either pass aÂ ToÂ value (same type asÂ <Link to>) with an optional secondÂ { replace, state }Â arg or
  • Pass the delta you want to go in the history stack. For example,Â navigate(-1)Â is equivalent to hitting the back button.

Advanced Route Definitions

This is where React Router really gets interesting. There is a lot of cool stuff you can do with routing to make more complex routes, easier to read, and overall much more functional.

Index Routes

Index routes can be thought of as â€œdefault child routesâ€. When a parent route has multiple children, but the URL is just at the parentâ€™s path, you probably want to render something into the outlet.

Now at â€œ/â€œ theÂ <Activity>Â element will render inside the outlet.
You can have an index route at any level of the route hierarchy that will render when the parent matches but none of its other children do.

NotFound Routes

When no other route matches the URL, you can render a â€œnot foundâ€ route usingÂ path="*". This route will match any URL, but will have the weakest precedence so the router will only pick it if no other routes match.

Dynamic Routing

The final route in the above example is a dynamic route that has a dynamic parameter of :id. Defining dynamic routes in React Router is as simple as putting a colon in front of whatever you want the dynamic part of your route to be. In our case our dynamic route will match any URL that starts with /book and ends with some value. For example, /books/1, /books/bookName, and /books/literally-anything will all match our dynamic route.

Pretty much always when you have a dynamic route like this you want to access the dynamic value in your custom component which is where the useParams hook comes in.

useParams()

TheÂ useParamsÂ hook returns an object of key/value pairs of the dynamic params from the current URL that were matched by theÂ <Route path>. Child routes inherit all params from their parent routes.

Routing Priority

In previous versions of React Router you had to order your routes a certain way to get the right one to render when multiple routes matched an ambiguous URL. V6 is a lot smarter and will pick the most specific match so you donâ€™t have to worry about that anymore. For example, the URL /teams/new matches both of these route,ButÂ teams/newÂ is a more specific match thanÂ /teams/:teamId, soÂ <NewTeamForm />Â will render.

Nested Routes

This is one of the most powerful features of React Router making it so you donâ€™t have to mess around with complicated layout code. The vast majority of your layouts are coupled to segments of the URL and React Router embraces this fully.
Routes can be nested inside one another, and their paths will nest too (child inheriting the parent).

This route config defined three route paths:

  • â€œ/invoicesâ€
  • â€œ/invoices/sentâ€
  • â€œ/invoices/:invoiceIdâ€
    Notice the inner component that changed with the URL (<SentInvoices> and <Invoice>). The parent route (<Invoices>) is responsible for making sure the matching child route is rendered with <Outlet>.

    Outlet

    An <Outlet> should be used in parent route elements to render their child route elements. This allows nested UI to show up when child routes are rendered. If the parent route matched exactly, it will render a child index route or nothing if there is no index route.

    Shared Layouts

  2. useOutletContext()

    Often parent routes manage state or other values you want shared with child routes. You can create your own context provider if you like, but this is such a common situation that itâ€™s built-into <Outlet />:If youâ€™re using TypeScript, we recommend the parent component provide a custom hook for accessing the context value. This makes it easier for consumers to get nice typings, control consumers, and know whoâ€™s consuming the context value. Hereâ€™s a more realistic example:

    Multiple Routes

Although you should only ever have a singleÂ <Router>Â in an app, you may have as manyÂ <Routes>Â as you need, wherever you need them. EachÂ <Routes>Â element operates independently of the others and picks a child route to render.

equivalent ç­‰æ•ˆçš„
assistive è¾…åŠ©çš„

mechanism æœºåˆ¶

SetUp

  • <BrowserRouter>Â orÂ <HashRouter>Â should be used when running in a web browser (which one you pick depends on the style of URL you prefer or need)
  • <StaticRouter>Â should be used when server-rendering a website
  • <NativeRouter>Â should be used inÂ React NativeÂ apps
  • <MemoryRouter>Â is useful in testing scenarios and as a reference implementation for the other routers
  • <unstable_HistoryRouter>Â is used with your ownÂ historyÂ instance.

Routing

  • matchPathÂ - matches a path pattern against a URL pathname
  • matchRoutesÂ - matches a set of routes against aÂ location
  • createRoutesFromChildrenÂ - creates a route config from a set of React elements (i.e.Â <Route>Â elements)

Navigation

  • useResolvedPathÂ - resolves a relative path against the currentÂ location
  • useHrefÂ - resolves a relative path suitable for use as aÂ <a href>
  • useLocationÂ andÂ useNavigationTypeÂ - these describe the currentÂ locationÂ and how we got there
  • useLinkClickHandlerÂ - returns an event handler to for navigation when building a customÂ <Link>Â inÂ react-router-dom
  • useLinkPressHandlerÂ - returns an event handler to for navigation when building a customÂ <Link>Â inÂ react-router-native
  • resolvePathÂ - resolves a relative path against a given URL pathname
